title: Top end of the property market makes strong comeback
text:
The weak Australian dollar is also attracting cashed-up expatriates from regional financial centres such as Singapore and Hong Kong, where continued unrest is increasing nervousness.

Sydney and Melbourne’s prestige suburbs are “clearly” driving the strongest spring season capital gains, CoreLogic said.

In the quarter to end-September, values in the top quartile of Sydney and Melbourne residential property rose by up to 4.6 per cent, more than double the gains in the lowest quartile, its analysis shows.

But prestige properties had fallen the most since the height of the boom, with Sydney still down about 14 per cent and Melbourne lower by around 12 per cent.

This time last year a large house in a prestigious, leafy Melbourne inner suburb that had 12 months earlier sold for more than $7 million dropped in value by more than $2 million, or 28 per cent.

The unrenovated four-bedroom, two-bathroom house on a 1210 square metre block, close to prestigious state and private schools, was passed in for $5.6 million, having been sold the previous November for $7.8 million.

Premium of 26 per cent

Advertisement

Last weekend a similar house, which is also unoccupied and in need of extensive renovation, sold at a premium of about 26 per cent, having been offered for around $5 million and selling for $6.3 million.

The heritage-listed Georgian-style three-bedroom, two-bath, 528-square-metre Toorak property is close to Melbourne’s Royal Botanic Gardens, top schools and is an easy commute to the central business district.

“Sellers this time last year thought their properties would be a cue in the rack,” said Rae Tomlinson, a partner with Marshall White Real Estate.

“The fire is back in the market,” Ms Tomlinson said, adding that buyer interest is the strongest in 18 months.

In Sydney, an off-the-plan buyer spent $140 million on a penthouse occupying the top three levels of Lendlease's One Sydney Harbour project at Barangaroo.

Stock in short supply

But buyers’ and sellers’ agents continue to complain that new stock, the fuel needed to build market heat, is in short supply.

Many vendors remain nervous about volatile markets and have delayed sales until there is stronger evidence of a market turnaround.

Advertisement

Emma Bloom, a director of buyers’ agency Morrell and Koren, said sellers are also worried that a shortage of suitable property will make it difficult to find a new property at a reasonable price.

Downsizers would have preferred more options for savings and investments to make the most of rising prices, Ms Bloom said. So many are choosing not to sell.

“Good houses are attracting four or five bidders,” Ms Bloom said. “The landscape is changing very quickly, even banks are predicting a 15 per cent price hike in Melbourne and Sydney.”

Mood swing

A survey of mortgage brokers by MyState bank revealed their mood has swung from pessimism to optimism in the eight months since the Hayne royal commission recommended sweeping changes to financial advice and lending.

But there are real estate trouble spots, typically involving safety and structural issues in high-rise apartments.

For example, analysis by BIS Oxford Economics revealed two in three Melbourne apartments sold off the plan during the past eight years had made no price gains, or have lost value, despite most of that period having benefited from boom prices and record immigration.

Simon Pressley, head of research for buyers' agent Propertyology, said buyers needed to be cautious, particularly investors in Melbourne and Sydney where vacancy rates and supply are increasing.

“Interest rate cuts have been a sugar fix and some recent responses are not sustainable,” Mr Pressley said.

He recommended property investors consider diversifying from Melbourne and Sydney into large regional centres, such as Cairns in Queensland, Ballarat in Victoria, or Armidale in NSW.
description: Property prices in the nation’s wealthiest postcodes are making the fastest recovery as rising sentiment, falling interest rates and supply shortages drive up demand.
